awd_titl_txt: Student Support: Twenty-Ninth Annual International Solid Freeform Fabrication (SFF) Symposium - An Additive Manufacturing Conference; Austin, Texas; 12-14 August 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this award is to provide support for 80 students to participate in the Twenty-Ninth Annual International Solid Freeform Fabrication (SFF) Symposium - An Additive Manufacturing Conference, to be held in Austin, Texas, 12-14 August 2019. The SFF Symposium is widely considered the premier academic conference on additive manufacturing (AM) related research in the world. In 2018, it brought together 683 researchers from universities, national laboratories, and companies from 19 countries around the world, who together presented 529 technical presentations and posters during the 3-day event. 

By attending and presenting their work at this symposium, students will have the opportunity to interact with leading researchers in their field, learn about cutting-edge research and challenging problems across the AM research community, and mature themselves professionally as future leaders in AM research and development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This grant helped to support student participation in the Thirtieth Annual International Solid Freeform Fabrication (SFF) Symposium.  The symposium took place on August 12-14, 2019 in Austin, Texas at The University of Texas at Austin.  It included papers on materials processing, modeling, process development, hybrid manufacturing and machine design for additive manufacturing.

 

The conference was attended by 702 persons representing 25 countries. The breakdown by affiliation was 12% governmental and non-profit laboratories, 6% industrial participants and the remainder from universities.  There were 103 universities represented, 39 of which were international.  There were 269 student attendees, 203 of whom came from US domestic universities. Of these, approximately 44% were students. There were 100 NSF travel award winners from a pool of 172 students.  Of these, 80 students were covered using the 2019 NSF conference grant (CMMI-1934397) and 12 students were covered by the SFF conference. 

 

The 2019 conference proceedings will include a total of 191 papers (~2500-pages) in the proceedings volume, and 9 additional papers have been scheduled to be published in special issues of the journal JOM. 

 

Intellectual Merit

 

Students experienced the multidisciplinary nature of the research, with various sessions emphasizing modeling, machine and process development, hybrid manufacturing, and materials processing for additive manufacturing.  We believe that documenting the changing state of the art in additive manufacturing in the meeting presentations and proceedings provides a valuable service for not only seasoned researchers but also the flux of new researchers, users, and students entering the field.

 

A student lunch and panel discussion were provided on August 13th, 2019. Cost was included in the registration fee. A panel discussion with a focus on navigating the transition into career positions in the AM field was conducted with ample opportunities for the students to ask questions. The panel featured four recent PhD graduates working in the field of AM in academia, industry, and a national lab. Information on the SFF Symposium was made available through a repository: http://sffsymposium.engr.utexas.edu/archive.  The website includes on-line registration forms, hotel information, general information, and a database of all previous proceedings articles available free of charge to anyone.

 

Broader Impacts

 

In addition to the benefits of direct meeting participation, students were able to network with the international additive manufacturing research community.  Wider dissemination was accomplished through the proceedings. The SFF Symposium serves as a primary forum for networking and dissemination of information dealing with research issues in freeform fabrication.  According to Ian Campbell, senior editor of the Rapid Prototyping Journal, “The SFF Symposium is to be regarded as the foremost international conference for rapid prototyping research (RPJ, 2003).  On a recent tally by AM experts on the most significant milestones in the history of AM, with the exception of the invention of specific AM processes, the inauguration of the SFF Symposium ranks highest1.  When asked which publications had greatest influence on the AM field, the Proceedings of the SFF Symposium tied with the only refereed archival journal dedicated solely to the AM field at the time, the British-based Rapid Prototyping Journal[1].  This same group ranked the SFF Symposium highest by over 50% to the next conference when asked what meeting contributed most to the development of the AM field1. The SFF Symposium Conference Proceedings are heavily cited in the archival literature, and it is anticipated that the 2019 Proceedings will be as well.

 

[1] Christopher L. Weber, et al., "The Role of the National Science Foundation in the Origin and Evolution of Additive Manufacturing in the United States", IDA Paper P-5091, IDA Science & Technology Policy Institute, Washington, DC, 2013.

 

Additive Manufacturing is an extremely broad and interdisciplinary field, encompassing mechanical engineering, electrical engineering, aerospace engineering, biomedical engineering, computer science and engineering, biology, design, materials science and engineering, and manufacturing science.  The topics covered at the SFF symposium impact the automotive, aerospace, orthopedics, dentistry, gaming, surgical planning, implants, marine, architecture, furniture, and art industries, among others. The 2019 conference served as a forum for this diverse interdisciplinary group of researchers to gather for the purpose of synergistic interaction and sharing of ideas and progress.

 

The meeting is an excellent networking opportunity for AM researchers from industry and academia. It is common for groups organized in geographically diverse locations to meet at the SFF Symposium for purposes of planning and executing various ventures. This conference serves as a meeting opportunity for researchers, a number of whom are involved to varying degrees in entrepreneurial activities. The networking aspect of the conference is strong and includes students who are able to meet and discuss research and tech transfer with world-class leading experts in the field.

 

 


[1] Christopher L. Weber, et al., "The Role of the National Science Foundation in the Origin and Evolution of Additive Manufacturing in the United States", IDA Paper P-5091, IDA Science & Technology Policy Institute, Washington, DC, 2013

 


Last Modified: 10/23/2019
Modified by: Guhaprasanna Manogharan
